Patch Set 19: Code-Review+1

Some boards have a GPIO presence along with EEPROM available to the BMC. One potential is to have the GPIO optionally probe the board's presence even if that board's EEPROM is corrupted, so we could detect the difference between "board not presence" vs "board eeprom corrupted".

This feature could potentially probe said inventory with an "unknown" value.

I assume with 'board' you mean a compute blade or sled within a larger system.

> This feature could potentially probe said inventory with an "unknown" value.

What do you mean by 'probe said inventory' ?

Do you mean you want to set an 'unknown' value in that inventory?

If the presence gpio is telling us that the board is present, the entity is still present. So 'Present' would be 'true', right? It would not be 'unknown'. 

On which interface would you suggest to set which value?


Can you provide an example EM configuration fragment to configure the feature you are describing?
I don't think this is designed to set Present on the item with the Probe statement?

Let me use a real system as an example:

We have minerva board with the 6 fan control boards,
each with presence GPIO pins: https://github.com/openbmc/linux/blob/dev-6.6/arch/arm/boot/dts/aspeed/aspeed-bmc-facebook-minerva.dts#L654 (PRSNT_FCB_[TOP|MIDDLE|BOTTOM]_[0|1]_N).

But we also have an EEPROM on these boards. So the primary inventory mechanism for this using EM is https://github.com/openbmc/entity-manager/blob/master/configurations/minerva_fanboard.json#L1280. It gets probed when the EEPROM is found and a valid FRUID is read.

One minor problem we have is to recognize the difference between a misplugged or faulty EEPROM of the fan-board vs a missing fan-board. So, I was seeing a potential here where we could mark this inventory as present but we also have an EM configuration for this.
In our example, your GPIO "Exposes" would be part of this chassis configuration https://github.com/openbmc/entity-manager/blob/master/configurations/minerva_cmm.json#L2.
We can add the fan board as an example. It is a good example for how gpio based inventory can be useful.
Did you mean exposes?
Yes.
Done

So EM will hold all of the inventory interfaces, including Inventory.Item that holds Present?

And is the JSON on line 126 a standalone file?  If so, if you were to check that into the repo, wouldn't every single system then start putting those ifaces on D-bus?

Or is that snippet an Exposes element inside another file? Could you specify that's the case if so?

After that is cleared up, I'm sure I'll have more questions

Yes, all of the interfaces. Since no other software will be taking responsibility for these items (other than presence daemon detecting it),
the EM can expose the required inventory interfaces.

Noted that the given json is just a configuration fragment, not a complete config.

Thanks for your review. Happy to discuss further concerns/ideas.
Currently EM properties are all read only except for the few that are in the allow list, which are then also persisted when written.  So Present would just have to be added to that.
Hm, let's discuss Patrick's point about EM possibly doing the presence itself. If it does it on it's own then maybe there is on need to have a Present=false state at all.

EM made a semi-attempt at adding the inventory.item iface today, but it never called initialize(), and also it didn't put on the PrettyName and Present properties that are required.  In the existing code, Present would always be true because it's being created after the probe matched.  I'm not sure then how this new interaction would work?

> EM made a semi-attempt at adding the inventory.item iface today

does it 'make' an attempt currently? Or are you talking about a patch that got merged today?

The new interaction is to answer the requirement for hardware inventory where the hardware is detected via gpio.

It may be special/proprietary hardware and there may not be a special daemon to handle it. Since it is not worth all that effort to make a special daemon and it is not needed for some components. But we still want the inventory and presence.

So the idea is for EM and some presence daemon to work together to accomplish what is currently being accomplished with phosphor-inventory-manager and a presence daemon.

EM will be better for that use case since it can be dynamic. phosphor-inventory-manager only supports the static configuration.

Right here https://github.com/openbmc/entity-manager/blob/master/src/entity_manager.cpp#L623 is what I was referring to.  So as it is now, nothing in EM holds a Present property.  Though I think that isn't really that relevant to what you have here after all.  It's easy enough to fix, I just didn't quite have the motivation to do it since nothing seems to be broken.

> EM will be better for that use case since it can be dynamic

Yep, makes sense. It would also be easy to add associations between say the items and their parent FRU if necessary for Redfish.

> So as it is now, nothing in EM holds a Present property.

'Present' property naturally complicates things. I'm also not sure if all other daemons properly handle this property. So if there is a dbus object with an inventory interface, and Present=false, will it be detected as absent by the other daemons?

For the static inventory the 'Present' property seems to have worked out, but imagine exposing large amounts of 'possibly present' inventory objects in dbus, leading to dbus bloat. 

Then all the daemons have to query 'Present' property before proceeding with anything.
feel free to re-open, but the design has shifted away from modifying 'Present' property, so I'm closing this as resolved.

could you add the "Exposes" [ ] around this just so it's clear?

And then would it work like:

```
chassis.json
{
  Exposes:
  [ 
     {
         Name:  cable0
         ...
     }
  ]
   ...
   Name:  Chassis
 }
```
  
  would have EM make the objects:
  
```
  inventory/system/chassis/Chassis
  inventory/system/cables/cable0  ?
       Present:  true/false
```
Done

This seems like a really big alternative design point that needs to be explored further.  I'd much prefer entity-manager to be extended to handle GPIO-based presence directly (or by probe matches on some other daemon) rather than state being spread across phosphor-gpio-monitor _and_ entity-manager.

EM allowing Presence to not always be true, but instead written by other processes, seems like a very large deviation from the current design.

Jagpal is working on leak detection and it seems like his design also needs entity-manager configuration after the detection of a leak-reporting-cable.  I would expect this feature and his feature to be closely related.  Your design should allow configuration to be exposed due to GPIO state (of the cable being presence) so that his daemon can consume the EM config for leaks reported by that cable.

> This seems like a really big alternative design point that needs to be explored further. I'd much prefer entity-manager to be extended to handle GPIO-based presence directly (or by probe matches on some other daemon) rather than state being spread across phosphor-gpio-monitor and entity-manager.

Makes sense to me, but this is explicitly out of scope of the EM design as per it's readme. That's from August 2020.

> Entity manager shall not directly participate in the detection of devices, and instead will rely on other D-Bus applications to publish interfaces that can be detected.

So it's good to have the EM maintainers here to discuss this.

If EM were to directly use the GPIOs to detect hw, it would simplify the logic.
Because the gpio can be requested synchronously, failing if another program already requested it. So there would be no need to expose configuration, wait for the other daemon to generate the property changed event, and then proceeding to probe other things.

There's been a few proposals over the years to put GPIO values directly on D-Bus, and they've all been shot down with https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/anti-patterns.md#dbus-interface-representing-gpios, not that that's being proposed here.

@Ed maybe you could weigh in on where you'd like to see GPIO presence for arbitrary FRUs being done.

Since the discussion on discord, i think the preference is to put it in dbus-sensors. https://discord.com/channels/775381525260664832/1273263354647023616/1283115358773051432

Reason being that it has various dbus utils for getting the configuration from entity-manager.

@Alexander Can you please mark this as a requirement (rather than possible extension) as we need this for exposing the inventory behind a board/cable when a cable is detected, especially, for liquid leak detectors through a pluggable cable.
Yes.

Not a blocking comment, but do you think naming something like 'gpio-device' would resonate better with 'fru-device' and accordingly the interfaces can be named GPIODeviceDetect and GPIODeviceDetected

```gpio-device``` can mean a lot of things. Is the daemon managing gpio controllers? Is driving gpios? Is it managing the inventory of gpio-detectable devices?

If we call it ```gpio-presence-sensor``` then it becomes clear what it does (sensing) the (presence) of devices via (gpios).

> the interfaces can be named GPIODeviceDetect and GPIODeviceDetected

updated the interface name.
This is needed as i mentioned in my previous comment.

Yes. I dug a little in the EM docs/sources and apparently any dbus interface should be supported for PROBE. So exposing a dbus interface should be sufficient for EM to be able to probe the detected component.

I only saw people probe an FruDevice interfaces before but apparently anything is possible. See ```configurations/blueridge_1s4u_chassis.json``` where they probe on some other dbus interface.

Here's a PoC of the presence sensor implementation
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/74651
Just so we get the whole picture, could you also do an EM config that does the GPIODevice probe for one of the above devices?

Yes, the below config is for probing on the newly detected fan board.

It probes on the 
```
xyz.openbmc_project.Configuration.GPIODeviceDetected
```
dbus interface.

I'm not certain this is the right name for the interface though.

Because the prefix
```
xyz.openbmc_project.Configuration.
```
is usually meant for configuration.

But also an inventory interface is not right, since the inventory should be exposed by entity-manager. The presence daemon does not need to know the type of device.
So it should not expose an inventory interface.

But i am also not certain that it's ok to just make up dbus interfaces without going through pdi (unless it's 'xyz.openbmc_project.Configuration.*' namespace).

So i chose the dbus interface as seen in the probe statement below.

Oh, not sure how I missed that.

In the design doc you can definitely make up new D-Bus interfaces, and then add them to PDI after the design is complete.

It is probably better to leave the Configuration ones for EM to do, and think of a new one for this.  Nothing is jumping out at me at the moment though.

> It is probably better to leave the Configuration ones for EM to do, and think of a new one for this. Nothing is jumping out at me at the moment though.

It is a form of inventory i guess. We have detected a device for in the inventory but it is unclear which one it is. It has a name which can be used to activate the probe the actual entity with entity-manager.

Sent the question on discord, since i also had some other queries about some pdi interfaces that do not have properties defined. Maybe someone has an idea, otherwise i can just adjust the design to use the proposed interface 

https://discord.com/channels/775381525260664832/1273263354647023616/1285254113344622614
Changed the interface the daemon exposes to ```xyz.openbmc_project.DeviceSlotPresence```, as suggested in discord.
My only query is, given that provides a source of information that drives an EM match, should we put it in the EM repository alongside fru-detect and the new devicetree-vpd-parser applications?

From the discussion, an existing downstream implementation seems to have done this in dbus-sensors repository. So i went with that approach. But i don't have a strong preference.

 https://discord.com/channels/775381525260664832/1273263354647023616/1283097267330351184

It looks like this has been done downstream multiple times in dbus-sensors.
https://discord.com/channels/775381525260664832/1273263354647023616/1283115358773051432


Since you are code owner in dbus-sensors but not in EM, i would need Ed's opinion (or another EM code owner) on if it's ok with him to do it in EM.
As one of the EM maintainers, I'm OK either way.
It was more of a musing-out-loud thought rather than a strong preference. But I do think putting it in dbus-sensors makes comprehending the flow of information harder.
Changed the wording in the design, to clarify that it will be done in EM repository.
nit: IPMI
Done
Why the whitespace?
nit: Add ":" at the end.
Done
Done
Since this isn't being formatted by prettier, I assume there is a syntax error in your JSON here.  Probably the trailing comma.
Done
nit: Add ":" to the end.
Done
nit: Add trailing punctuation throughout the document as appropriate. (ex. a period here).
Acknowledged
I can't tell what this YAML is attempting to specify.  Are you missing a sentence before this?
Done

1. Can we put this under Inventory?  Or should it go under Configuration?

2. I don't really like "Slot" being used here because this can also be used for things that don't plug into slots.

- 1 From my perspective it's neither an inventory item nor a configuration item. The configuration item is  ```xyz.openbmc_project.Configuration.GPIODeviceDetect```

and the inventory item is 

```
xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Cable```

or 

```
xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Fan```

or other item. The 'gpio-presence-sensor' is not intended to expose configuration or inventory items. For the configuration, that is already exposed by EM. 
I would like to avoid exposing it as an inventory item because this interface will be used to probe the actual inventory item. Also to avoid anyone using this outside the intended context.

- 2 Yes. We can rename to 'EntityPresence' which is more generic.

Since we resolved this in discord as 
```xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Source.DevicePresence```

We need names that are much more robust than this.  I would suggest that we follow the conventions in phosphor-dbus-sensors where we require a file like `com.meta.Hardware.BMC` to enumerate the hardware models.  This might not fly with the entity-manager maintainers, but we need to come up with something to ensure uniqueness.
Added a small section to cover this. Since "Name" is just a string, namespacing with content like ```com.$Vendor.$PlatformX.$DeviceY``` is not a problem.
But shouldn't the example be something that is acceptable?  "fanboard0" seems too simple that it would always be rejected, so why use it as the example?

While this is an interesting idea, there is no precedence for doing this in our CI already.  Are you trying to do too much work?

There are other methods to either a) run big portions of the service as a thread within a gtest process (https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-logging/blob/c8da4fe91cbc1b2befd07198e35e647355247e4e/test/log_manager_dbus_tests.cpp#L22) or launch just enough of the manager on a test.entity_manager connection in a separate thread.
I was more concerned with having a way to test it at all and communicating that. When the design is agreed upon i can have a look at what's the state of integration testing in EM and adjust to that.
Cleaned up this section to communicate that there is multiple options for testing and that it should not be difficult or block the design.

(fwiw, it does look like our CI system already launches a separate dbus-daemon since it all happens in a Docker container anyhow.  You don't need `dbus-run-session`, except that if you want to ensure two different test cases don't collide.)

Am I understanding correctly that this daemon makes it so that entity-manager can do probes based on GPIO bit readings for a device described in another entity-manager JSON config?

I think it would be good to have a statement at the bottom of 'problem description' that summaries the solution the rest of the doc describes.

A design doc I recently got merged ended the problem description section with

>This proposal describes a method of handling for hardware where HW ID data is gathered from device tree file paths for Entity-Manager consumption.

And i always thought 'Problem Description' section is just for describing the problem, independent of the solution.

Added new summary sections to the 'Proposed Solution' section to make it clearer.
nit: phosphor-inventory-manager*
Done

Could we get a 'high level flow' here that the describes how the gpio-presence-sensor design works? 

A lot of the info is included in the details linked and elsewhere in the doc, but I think a short, low-detail summary of the steps involved here at the top would be nice.

This is what ended up getting accepted on the doc I recently got merged, just in case it's helpful 

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/designs/entity-manager-hw-id-vpd-discover-via-device-tree.md#proposed-design

I can rework the explanations to go from less to more detail.
There is 2 new sections now 
'Forward flow summary' and 'Reverse flow summary'.

Also - since daemon code is starting to get submitted to Gerrit, have you already pushed a new interface YAMLs to phosphor-dbus-interfaces for discussion there?

If not, I'd recommend doing that sooner than later, since all kinds of discussion can happen around small details there.

In my own daemon's case, I spent waaaay too much time debating with folks over how to name the thing, then when I finally polished and submitted it, it got an almost immediate "no way we're doing any of that, use an existing interface" :p 

(I suspect it won't be the same same case here, though)

> Also - since daemon code is starting to get submitted to Gerrit, have you already pushed a new interface YAMLs to phosphor-dbus-interfaces for discussion there?

Did not push anything there, since the design is still being discussed. If the dbus interface descriptions are unclear, that's a review concern i can try to resolve.

> If not, I'd recommend doing that sooner than later, since all kinds of discussion can happen around small details there.

If people approve my design here (which already includes the dbus interfaces) and then reject it later in the PDI repo, then i should probably just resign and look for a simpler job.

> In my own daemon's case, I spent waaaay too much time debating with folks over how to name the thing, then when I finally polished and submitted it, it got an almost immediate "no way we're doing any of that, use an existing interface"

That's unfortunate. From my experience, design documents are the way to go to get agreement on something from multiple people, then implement it. It's a slow process but practical in the many-repository environment.

btw thanks for your review and feedback :)

>If people approve my design here (which already includes the dbus interfaces) and then reject it later in the PDI repo, then i should probably just resign and look for a simpler job.

In my experience, it's more that folks with a strong opinion on fine details like exactly what's going to be included in dbus-interface or not might not necessarily be catching design change discussions happening in docs. 

I ran into that a ton myself - where folks reading and discussing the designs at a high level might have very different views than the folks maintaining specific repos being considered for landing one change or another.

That's part of the fun of big open source projects, I'm finding! :p

If your design requires a new D-Bus interface, I'd say there's no harm in submitting what you think should work with your in-progress code so the maintainers and reviewers there can make weigh in sooner than later if you're going to need to adjust your design somehow based on repo-specific restrictions.

This might be a complex enough edge case to not document here but want to make sure you are considering it.

The board containing the GPIO / connector itself could be removed.  In that case EM will remove the configuration, so `gpio-presence-sensor` itself needs a matcher for that.

Yes, this is an implementation detail that all services need to consider that get their configuration from EM.

I can add a diagram to clarify the flow and also add a new section to explain what happens when the configuration is removed from dbus.
Can we go ahead and add this to PDI?

There are no configuration interfaces in PDI, right?
It's EM specific internal dbus interfaces.

Are the EM maintainers on board with this?
Or will it be only this configuration interface.

That would be very inconsistent, to have one lonely configuration interface in PDI.

As the famous saying goes:

> "The best time to document your code was yesterday; the second best time is now..." - Mark Twain (1492)

https://imgflip.com/i/99k2ig

Is this blocking the design now?

Adding or not adding the configuration interface to PDI is not part of the design.
It's a detail of the implementation/design process.

That's entirely between EM maintainers and PDI maintainers, if they now require configuration interfaces to be in PDI. I did not see any announcement from them that this is the new direction.

Also, if that were the case and it were required, the dbus interface can still be added to PDI after the design is merged. Since the configuration is part of the design document, people can already review it here.

I don't want to have design discussions about the same thing with the same people in N different repositories.
nvm, i have to rework the configuration json / interface to make it compatible with PDI. Right now it's incompatible since EM is creating N different dbus interfaces for N gpios.

done, added a patch for the configuration interface
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/75740
Why is polarity a string?
It's EM configuration. Just grep for ```Polarity``` in EM configuration folder. They all define it as a string.

This has nothing to do with the "largeness" of the system.  _All_ configs go into entity-manager.  They _all_ have to be unique among themselves.

If we have two different people using `DevicePresence("fanboard0")`, entity-manager will load both of those configs, even if it isn't appropriate for the system.

If people have config that is specific to a system, they can use EM ```AND``` conjunction in their PROBE statement. But i agree that that's inefficient and could lead to overhead within EM.

Adjusted the statement to avoid any mention of "Name" that is not namespaced.

Can you make a pointer to that previous work (either designs and/or code) and add in the alternatives section some discussion on why this previous work did not come to fruition?  How is this proposal better?

> Can you make a pointer to that previous work

This is the 'existing design' link under 'Background and References'.

Since people reading the design should also read all the links and references, it will be clear to them that i am referring to that design.

> some discussion on why this previous work did not come to fruition? 

As noted in 'Background and References', the design was only partially implemented.

So the reason it did not come to fruition is that it was partially implemented.

If someone is interested to know, they can go via
existing design -> linchuyuan@google.com -> gerrit search
and find the patchset https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/45997
which after 49 revisions was abandoned.

There are many comments. Everyone can make their own research into that patchset. I don't want to draw any conclusion or summary about the reviewer's opinion there.

Also https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/45095
which is the cable interface which is currently being used.

> How is this proposal better?

I would not say it's better, it's different and more general. The existing design focuses only on cables, and focuses on the example of one gpio to detect a cable and make a cable inventory.

This design focuses on gpio based hardware inventory in general and not only limited to cables. The downside of this design is that it does not directly provide the cable inventory. It provides an Inventory Source on which to probe other configuration. Which may then provide the cable inventory, sensors and/or other things.

The main problems with the existing design is that it was not implemented.
It could have been easily expanded to multiple gpios.

Changed the link to the existing design to make it even more clear that it is from Chu Lin.
